title: At close of business on 4 May 2022, will the upper limit of the Federal Reserve's target range for the federal funds rate be lower, the same, or higher than it was at close of business on 16 March 2022?
preds: They have telegraphed they will raise rates
Passage of time and recent commentary
<0.5% chance of a severe market crash in the next two weeks
Relentless Fed tightening policy for next few months.
Powell's comments today are hawkish and suggest a potential faster rate of tightening, so it's pretty much a sure thing we get a hike in May, but leaving 1% in the event of a black swan.

Supply-side inflation will not be impacted significantly unless there is a great decrease in demand for goods.  This reduced demand will be a combination of increased interest rates and shifting of consumer habits from wants to needs.

Fed is expecting 6-7 hikes this year, if we take them at their word we should expect at least a 25bps move, potentially a 50bps one. If inflation remains significantly elevated and the job market remains tight there is no reason to not believe they will do what they say. I am leaving a 10% margin of error for covering cases where inflation comes down by itself via supply chain issues resolving, economic headwinds caused by the Ukraine crisis and recent commodities spike, or a recession cause the Fed to reconsider their current tightening trajectory.

Increasing my confidence in a hike after considering Bullard's comments+Waller's comments this morning: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-03-18/waller-favors-fed-considering-half-point-hikes-at-coming-months.
Powel is talking about 6 increases this year.

Fed expected to lift rates 6 more times this fiscal year after meeting today... Seems like market volatility was not as strong of a force as expected to keep rates lower in the short to medium term...
The latest dot plot seems to be expecting hikes at every meeting, going up 20%. https://twitter.com/LiveSquawk/status/1504156885951336455/photo/2
25bps inc and 6 future means this is 'almost' certain now.

Based on the Fed rate hike today and expectation for ongoing increases in the target range, I suspect another 25 bps hike in May. That said, I'm leaving some room for adjustment given ongoing geopolitical crises and potential new covid strains etc.

https://edition.cnn.com/2022/03/11/investing/premarket-stocks-trading/index.html
Recession in the next year: ~35% If that were evenly distributed it would be ~8% per quarter. But Russia shock is going to set in very quickly. The fed may slow rate increases just to play it safe. A catastrophic recession would result in a rate cut. I think even the talk of recession may end up becoming a self-fulfilling prophecy

Current global 'turmoil' could throw a wrench in the Fed Rate increase schedule - as market volatility and below normal global growth due to supply chain disruptions and economic sanctions could tamper down growth by themselves, and make the Fed hesitate on raising rates too much. Not to say rates will not increase at all - but the pace may be slower than originally projected.

GIven Jay Powell's comments today it seems like we're more likely to have 25bps in March, rather than 50bps, which leads me to be more confident in two conscutive hikes rather than one 50bps, break, back to schedule. Hence I am increasing the likelihood of a hike here and it's HIGHER. What holds me back is 1) the off chance we get 50 in march and 2) a cooling of inflation that leads the fed to pause in May.
expecting to see consistent and steady hikes for a while

Again, another forecast affected by current invasion in Ukraine and odds of escalation of conflict. 
The NYT reported today that the Fed Reserve isn't likely to change course because of the invasion. 
But invasion is likely to caused commodities prices to go much higher.
Economists say the price of oil matters most because crude prices can drive up inflation and slow down the global economy. "What happens to oil could also determine whether the Fed continues a brisk pace of hiking after it raises interest rates in March or ultimately slows the pace due to growth concerns."
So far, Pres. Biden said sanctions will not include energy sector yet. Brent oil went up over $105 today, WIT close to a hundred but both went back down after Biden spoke. 
This, however, I wouldn't expect to last for long. Putin is putting all on this conflict and will not stop at anything to inflict major pain if he can't get away with what he wants, or if getting what he wants is too costly, which is starting to look like it will.
Going up more to follow the crowd and some of the latest opinions suggesting there could be rate increases at every meeting this year.
Updated based on the lastest number from FedWatch Tool.

Given Fed commentary, inflation prints, I am increasing the liklihood of higher. I am not OVERLY convinced yet as they may move 50bps in March (which could be enough to "skip" May) or there could be a black swan like Russia/Ukraine or variants that require them to skip May.

There are five possible scenarios:  1. Hold flat in March, then increase in May (0% chance)
2. Increase 25 basis points in March, followed by another increase in May (44% chance)
3. Increase 25 basis points in March, then hold steady in May (1% chance)
4. Increase 50 basis points in March, then hold steady in May (19% chance)
5. Increase 50 basis points in March, then increase again in May (36% chance)
back to back hikes following liftoff in march is priced into market, barring exogenous event like russia invasion of ukraine, seems extremely likely rates are hiked in march as well as may
50% increase of a rate increase at the May meeting, no prospect for a rate decrease.

After declining on a quarterly, seasonally adjusted annualized (QSAA) basis from July through September PCE core inflation, the Fed's preferred measure of inflation has reaccelerated.  The measure shows faster growth than the year-on-year rate commonly reported in headlines and over three times the FOMC's stated 2% average inflation target.  Meanwhile, the labor conditions show both job creation and unemployment at levels consistent with a healing labor market.  In the context of the dual mandate, a near zero policy rate is well away from neutral monetary policy, implying the need for repeated and relatively frequent increases in interest rates.  The 30-day Fed Funds Futures as of Feb 11 are pricing  nearly 50 basis points (bps) of rate cuts between March and June (and about 150 bps over the seven remaining meetings this year).    Given the gap between current policy rates and neutral, a precipitous fall in inflation/surge in unemployment would forestall a rate hike at the May FOMC meeting.   That seems unlikely given the current momentum in prices and the labor market.   A pause in May could occur were the Fed to hike 50 bps in March and inflation decelerate.  The May FOMC meeting will have March PCE core inflation.   With the December data, that year-on-year inflation is already 4.6% and even with a halving of the current monthly rate of inflation, will be above 5% this March.
Going down a bit; I think I was a bit too overconfident with my previous forecast.
I’m guessing raises almost definitely in both March and May, and most likely in June as well. Inflation just hit 7.5%
Inflation continues to run hotter than expected. More likely to see >4 rate hikes this year, including in May.
+10 on a rate increase on inflation numbers being a little higher than had been expected.

Hedging toward the crowd a bit, though I'm more uncertain. I'm not sure they would want to hike at back to back meetings, though it's more possible than I assumed because it looks like it's historically more common than I thought. [1] I also assumed it would be more likely at meetings with a Summary of Economic Projections [2] which I think is normally the case but looking at [1] it doesn't seem like a hard rule by any means. And banks are mostly estimating 5 hikes in 2022. [3] At 4 hikes my guess would be at the economic projections meetings in March, June, September, and December, but 5 makes May more likely I think. Finally this CME group tool [4] is giving a very high chance of hikes in all of March, May, and June. But if I'm understanding it correctly it gives a 0% chance of no hike in May, which to me seems implausibly low so I'm wondering if there's a weird methodology quirk and it makes me discount their information some. Overall I feel that the FED sees inflation as higher than expected but likely to ease in 2022 due to smoothing of supply chain issues, and I would think they wouldn't want to raise rates too suddenly and risk hurting markets. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Federal_Open_Market_Committee_actions [2] https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/fomccalendars.htm [3] https://twitter.com/FerroTV/status/1488091231888498690 [4] https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html
Assuming upper limit will increase at March 15-16, 2022 meeting, it is likely FOMC will keep the trend at its May meeting.

Likely higher based on their current posturing, but depends on how the market and economy fare after March. Given that they've switched to a "control inflation" focus vs a "jobs" focus, I'm thinking that another hike will happen unless things really take a rapid dive.
Inflationary pressure from raw materials, labor shortages will likely continue, feeding through into higher interest rates generally
March rate hike seems very likely, and I’m putting some more probability on not having two consecutive rate hikes.

Rotating toward two consecutive 25 basis point hikes. I previously assumed they would let the markets settle a bit before the second hike.  Increase in March = 95%
If yes, increase again in May = 50%
If No, increase in May = 95%

The latest Powell comments leave a lot of flexibility (not drawn on reducing balance sheet or number of scale of rate hikes) whilst clearly signalling a rate hike in March and a view that the FED needs to act and has reasonable room to do so without a disproportionate impact on jobs. It is difficult to assess the probability of two rate rises in succession. In 2018 the rate rises were each quarter (and so not the May meeting) and this is the best precedent but not a particularly good one as inflation is much more concerning now. I suspect the base case is 25bps March Jun Sep and Dec but could be faster if inflation continues to rise.

Signalled clearly that a March hike is going to happen. Only way it doesn't is if the markets really do tank and give the Fed something to worry about, but it's hard to see them not hiking even then given the signal that would send. Given the market volatility at the moment, I suspect that it is now unlikely that we will see back-to-back hikes.
They seem likely to hike in March, and I think back to back is unlikely, but I'm hedging toward the crowd.
It's sounding more and more like they will raise rates in March, so the question is, will they ALSO raise them in May?

Powell indicated there will be a series of  rate increases  like every meeting. I predict 25 basis points every meeting 
March April and perhaps May.
It takes 6 months to cycle through to real economy

Given the FOMC meeting today and Powell's comment, it appears there is a greater liklihood of back-to-back hikes. That said a 50bps hike in March is not off the table which, in my view, would halt the need for a May hike. But at this point it seems a Mar (25bps), May (25bps) is getting more likely to tame inflation. This puts a higher weighting on "Higher" than "Same"
Assuming an 82% chance of a rate hike in March, a 25% conditional probability of a second in May, and a 95% conditional probability of a May increase if they stand pat in March.

Firs rate increase for the year expected to come after March Fed meeting. Interest rate future markets pricing/expecting 4-5 rate increases this year. Assuming the first increase comes in March - Fed will need to increase rates every .333 months to meet the 4 rate increases per month expectation, and .444 rate increases per month to meet the 5 rate increase expectations. 2 Months between March and May means that to stay on track with expectations, the Fed will only need to have raised rates between  .667 - .889 'Times' to meet expectations for the NUMBER of increases that are expected. I.e. in order to stay on track with both ends of the 'Number of times' rates are raised, they can have 0 rate increases in this time.  Now - assuming that they are trying to be Proactive with the policy changes and rate increases - there is a good chance that rates are raised more at the beginning of the year than the end of the year, shown by the higher probability of 'Higher' rates, but much closer than my original estimates.
4 rate hikes expected this year, March, May, September, December each of about .25. Fed meeting this upcoming week.
Changing forecast to reflect the passage of time and situation.

Adjusting down to account for stronger Fed action in March which might cause a pause in May. Still think we will see a May hike as inflation runs hot, but less likely low that some are calling for 50bps in March.
25 basis points in March and 25 basis points in May
The increasing likelihood of a March hike reduces the chances of one happening in May.
The Eurodollar futures market between March and May is currently pricing a roughly 80% chance of a rate hike at the May FOMC meeting.
Going down a bit because I went up in it happening in March. I think the probability that they raise rates both months is fairly low.
will pause after hiking in march, and hike again in july

A lot has changed on this file given the recent Fed mtgs, Minutes, payrolls data, and CPI print. All in, the wisdom of markets (options) are pricing in a March hike. WHich suggests to me that the "Same" bucket is growing in liklihood (March hike, then skip raising on the next mtg). But just this morning Harker mentioned they'd be open to more than 3 hikes this year. And consensus seems to be growing for 4 hikes. So now we have:
1. Hike in March, no hike May (SAME)
2. Hike in March, hike in May (HIGHER)
3. No hike March, hike in May (HIGHER)
4. No hike March, no hike May (SAME) It seems increasingly likely of a March hike...which gives me a split verdict...given the rate at which they're tapering, I can't see two subsequent raises. So I'm tilting further odds towards the Same bucket. With that said, I see equal probability of 2 & 3 scenario. So I'm keeping some odds on HIGHER.

It seems almost a sure thing that rates will be higher on May 4th than they are TODAY. Of course that’s not the question and the risk is one of timing if the Fed raises in March and then waits until later in the summer for a second increase. But with banks now looking at 4 hikes in 2022 and the hawkish minutes from the last meeting, still seems likely that we see increases in March and May.

The historic trend would indicate a stair-step with a rise followed by a plateau skipping a meeting to the next rise. However given how fearful everyone is right now it feels better than even they will either wait till May or rise in March and again in May.
Up 10 on a good point by @Nik and my reasoning here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1380366

The Fed can start raising its rates in March or May. If they start in March - the last month of the taper - it would be because they see the matter as urgent, in which case they would continue with another hike in May. If they don't start in March, they have to start in May, because further wait would be untenable. Either way, the May rate will be higher than the March one.  The only way the May rate is the same as in March would be if the economy crashes in the next few months, which would be a major surprise.
Shifting up on bin 2 as there are now two ways for that outcome to occur: Hold flat through May and increase in March then hold in May.
Coming down as I think the chances of a rate hike in March seem to be increasing, though I think May is more likely than March.

https://www.nytimes.com/live/2022/01/05/business/stock-market-economy-news?campaign_id=51&emc=edit_mbe_20220106&instance_id=49556&nl=morning-briefing%3A-europe-edition&regi_id=77825025&segment_id=78829&te=1&user_id=dc6933c94fc82416d25dd297622374d1#wall-street-slips-ahead-of-the-release-of-the-minutes-of-the-feds-meeting " . . . minutes from the Federal Reserve’s December meeting showed that officials discussed raising interest rates at a quicker pace than they had anticipated . . .
. . . .
“It may become warranted to increase the federal funds rate sooner or at a faster pace than participants had earlier anticipated,” the minutes showed. Fed officials had already indicated in December that they expected to raise interest rates three times in 2022, something that was repeated in the release on Wednesday. The market’s response last month was muted, but investors reacted strongly to the detailed minutes with a growing sense that higher interest rates were inevitable as the outlook for the economy has only improved since then. Government bond yields are seen as a proxy for investor expectations about interest rates, and they jumped on Wednesday. The yield on 10-year Treasury notes climbed as high as 1.71 percent, a level not seen since April, when bond yields were spiking over concerns about inflation. Higher bond yields can dampen investor interest in riskier investments like stocks. And big technology stocks, which have proved sensitive to changing views on interest rates, were sharply lower. The tech-heavy Nasdaq composite fell 3.3 percent, its worst one-day performance since late February. Alphabet, Google’s parent company, fell 4.6 percent while Microsoft dropped 3.8 percent and the Facebook parent company Meta dropped 3.7 percent. Apple fell more than 2.5 percent and Amazon slid nearly 2 percent. The sheer size of the tech giants — Apple was a $3 trillion colossus as of Monday — means they can influence the direction of major benchmarks like the S&P 500. Fed officials had said in December that the central bank would quicken its pullback on large-scale purchases of government-backed bonds to cool down inflation, paving the way for the Fed to raise interest rates as soon as March. . . . .
. . . 
One reason investors may have reacted strongly on Wednesday, rather than in December when the central bank first said it would move more quickly to remove economic support, is recent data about the Omicron variant of the coronavirus, said Anu Gaggar, a strategist at Commonwealth Financial Network. The emergence of the variant, in late November, had created an uncertain outlook for the economy that might have discouraged the Fed from acting too quickly, Ms. Gaggar said. But data now suggests that the new variant is milder than initially feared and that the wave of infections may peak soon. “It appears the economic impact of the Omicron variant is going to be much more muted than what we thought in December, when the Fed announced the taper and the rate hikes,” she said. “When you factor that in, the market is actually starting to believe that the Fed will do what they say they will do.” Two key reports of economic data will arrive over the next week and help guide the Fed . . . . December’s job report is scheduled to be released on Friday, and economists expect a gain of about 400,000 jobs last month. A separate report on Tuesday showed that the number of Americans quitting their jobs is the highest on record. The Fed minutes noted that members were closely watching the labor market, with some meeting participants saying that work force conditions may already be consistent with maximum employment. And the Labor Department will report fresh data on consumer prices in December next Wednesday. The Consumer Price Index climbed by 6.8 percent in the year through November amid strong demand and continued supply-chain disruptions.

The Fed is likely to raise interest rates in response to rising inflation.  That inflation is driven by a combination of increased demand (American’s tended to save and hoard during the pandemic, and have increasingly been starting to spend) and decreased supply (COVID restrictions have limited both production and trade globally).  The FOMC recently determined that it would stop purchasing assets in order to accelerate raising rates in 2022.  It is likely to first raise rates at the May meeting, and one would expect it to raise it a further 1 or 2 times in 2022 and again in 2023 in order to tackle inflation, although this could be mitigated by a decline of growth if COVID or something else cause any reduction of productivity.

The longer 2022 continues without a rate hike - The more likely May will be higher. Inflation expected to increase, and administration will be under pressure to do something to stop it if that doesn't change.
First rate hike mostly likely in May unless covid improves dramatically.
The only direction in the near future is up.
-5 on higher, possible it could raise before.
Inflation is clearly a huge problem and it appears that the time of quantitative easing is ending. I would bet that rates are going up in 2022.

Inflation is going to put central bankers in a pickle, developing countries have tagged along the big boys suppressing rates now they have real inflation and worse is that they were lied about it using the “temporary” term but a year and going is more persistent that the term temporary was understood a year ago. So little by title, rates will to be raised to pair the differentials created so far the big boys keep buying the dollar to calm the “raisers” but there is a limit to what buying dollars can do without in itself is also an inflationary ……influence.
Adjusting slightly as Omicrom expected to be milder and so less likely to disrupt the economy.

The odds of a recession occurring in a given year are something like 1/10. So odds in a given month are maybe 1/120. So odds of a crash in 1.5 months between mid March and early may are like ~1.25%. Might round up to be safe since the economy is still in a weird state, and rate hikes probably increase the chance of a recession. So 1-2% chance that the Fed raises rates in Jan/March and then is forced to pull back by May should not be discounted

If the Fed is scheduled to meet in Jan, Mar, May, Sept & Dec,  IF it is going to raise the rate 3 times in 2022 (a consensus opinion)
IF they they don't begin to do so, as Powell said, until they've stopped buying bonds, estimated to be in late March,  
then they'll be raising them at the May, Sept & Dec meetings.   Maybe. Unless politics, Omicron, inflation & unemployment rates, the bond buy-back program is completed earlier or later, or something else comes up.  What if BBB is passed?  What impact will the approaching mid-term elections have on the decision in Sept? Sounds like a no-brainer to me.  LOL! Thanks to the following forecasters for helping me understand this question and what is involved:
@mjsmith, @kevins, @Hesch, @JPH, @MarkEliason, @BMarshall10
Down a bit as it's possible the hike could come as soon as March, so I can't be too confident here. May drop further after considering more.

Last week the FOMC showed 12 out of 18 FOMC members expect at least three rate raises next year. Using the wisdom of markets (not only on this site but using the futs/options market) it appears there is a high probability (~46%) of a hike in March, with reasonably odds for a May or June hike as well (32%, 48% respectively). But this question is interesting because it's conditional on what happens in March. I.e. do they raise in March or push off to May? And if they raise is March, will they feel they have to raise in May as well or push off to June (which odds seem to imply). Odds markets seems to imply a March, *June* (edited), and Sept (or Dec) raise to satisfy the Fed's 3 in '22 target. @JPH summarized this fairly well. With that said --- I willk note that Jay Powell was pretty clear that they'll only think about raising rates when the taper is complete -- and current estimates suggest that is by March. So I think it would be too aggressive to complete the aggressive+liftoff rates in the same month. Considering there is already uncertainty with how the market will react to the completion of the taper. So if we do hike in March, its doubtful we'll need a May hike (=same). I'll split the difference between the crowd on here (30% same) and the wisdom of futures (45%) and call it 37%. With that, I'll put the remainder on higher which accounts for a hold off in March and a raise in May. Not marries to this but think it's fair to believe we hold off in March (on account the taper was tightening enough) and raise in May to stifle any lingering inflationary pressures. Leaves the door for a Sept hike+Dec hike if needed to satisfy three hikes.

There are a lot of signals being given by the Fed that a rate hike is due early next year, which would tie in with a raised target rate (https://www.ft.com/content/6c6b6c99-9e46-406d-a7f7-39b509542097). Given that inflation is still rising and is way above the target, there will almost certainly be a rate rise in the first half of next year, save for some economic disaster (could be covid related or otherwise). I think the chance of a rate hike is at ~90-95% to occur in the first half of next year. One question as @Anneinak points out is whether a rate hike takes place before or at March's meeting or not. I think a lot of this depends on whether inflation continues to spike in the numbers released for December (released Jan 12th), January (released Feb 10th) and February (released March 10th). The December numbers will be released before the January Fed meeting (https://www.bls.gov/schedule/news_release/cpi.htm), and the January + February numbers before the March meeting. But at the May meeting they will only have March inflation numbers - not April.  My feeling with this is that even if the Fed raises rates in March, that doesn't mean they won't be raising rates again in May. Going in March would signal that inflation is more of a worry than previously anticipated, and they are unlikely to see effects of a higher rate by May. In fact, as mentioned above, they will only have one additional data point which their interest rate hike would have affected (March inflation data) - and even then only partially. So my forecast is based on:
95% rate hike first half next year (e.g. base 'Same' rate is 5%) Assuming this happens
50% Only Jan/March sees a rate hike 
50% Only May sees a rate hike
50% May sees a rate hike following a Jan/March Hike ~71% higher/29% same

The options seem to be: Raise rates in March (which would be marginally before the end of tapering) and not May (=Same),  in both months (=Higher) or not to raise in March and to do so in May (= Higher) or to do so  in neither (=Same). Tapering is expected to end in March and the earliest rates raised is May (after tapering ends).  This is the central case scenario but there are several months to go and the economy remains very uncertain with conflicting pressures of inflation and rising Omicrom cases.  I am hedging a little for now and not fully committing to the central case.

Per public comments, the Fed will not raise rates prior to finishing its bond buying taper. According to a survey of economists published in the FT, most don't expect that to happen until the end of March. The May FOMC meeting will be the first one after the bond buying taper. As long as inflationary conditions persist, as I expect them to under omicron, the Fed will be under pressure to raise rates by May. There is a slight chance that they will need to hold steady on rates if the economy is struggling, however.

I've been wondering why the Admins selected the dates they did.  (They usually have a reason!)  @Ed321 & @Bmarshall10 mentioned that it might be related to Fed Reserve Bd meetings. I just found:   FED : FOMC Publishes 2022 Meeting Schedule
January 25-26 (Tuesday-Wednesday)
March 15-16 (Tuesday-Wednesday)
May 3-4 (Tuesday-Wednesday) So this question is about if the Fed will change the target range for the federal funds rate at the May meeting, right?  hm.   I had been thinking that if they changed the rate at the March meeting, it would count, but re-reading the question, a change at the March meeting will already be in effect at the close of the business day March 16th (unless the March meeting gets postponed!). Another thing that would impact this is if the May meeting gets postponed or a decision isn't reached by the end of the day on May 4th. @Hesch

Indeed an interesting question as mentioned by @Anneinak
"This is an interesting question because it is asking if there will be a rate change during a 7 week period about 3 months from now; I don't recall us having many other questions like this." https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1369160  https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/DFEDTARU

@Ed321 This is a crystal ball forecast.There are too many variables in play at this moment to make an objective economic analysis on what the Federal Reserve may or may not do in May of 2022. Yes ,they do have a meeting and yes, based on present data on inflation they are going to decrease quantitative easing or in plain English-stop the purchase of corporate bonds.They will still purchase U.S.Treasuries as always.As I stated once before if the rate increases are too fast and too high the cure for inflation is a recession. I was self employed during the inflationary recession of the 1070’s-1080’s and it was brutal.However,Paul Volker’s cure though painful worked.
I think 3 rate hikes are expected next year and I would guess they'll begin around May.

The dates are significant because the FOMC meetings 3/15-3/16 and 5/3-5/4 so question implies a rate hike at the May meeting. Last week Fed doubled the rate of taper to $30 per month, implying that the tapering will be done ~March. Fed has stated that it will not raise rates until tapering is done because it would be counteracting. Current "dot plot" shows all 18 members expect at least 1 hike in 2022, with the vast majority expecting at least 2 hikes. Fed stopped using the word "transitory" for current inflation, giving cover for strong action in 2022 and 2023. Odds strongly favor multiple hikes, likely 3, starting in March or May. Initial forecast strongly favors a May hike, with lesser possibility that data forces either earlier more dramatic action or outright delay which could leave rates steady in May. Would need significant counter evidence to suggest a decrease in May 2022, so probability very low for now. Will adjust as data progresses.

Subjective initial forecast. I don’t see any special significance of these specific dates. I would not necessarily expect any changes to occur before ~2Q anyway, since the Fed would presumably finish tapering before changing their target range.
This is an interesting question because it is asking if there will be a rate change during a 7 week period about 3 months from now; I don't recall us having many other questions like this.

The FED has not committed to anything. All future tapering and federal funds changes are data dependent. If they were serious about fighting inflation they would already have stopped tapering and would be raising the federal funds rate already. The current monetary policy is still expansionary, still adding money to the money supply, so they are still pouring gasoline on the inflation fire. This means therefore that they are still trying to prop up the market, and if the stock market starts to stumble from the tapering they will find some excuse, probably covid, to delay raising rates. So the question is, what is the stock market going to do between now and March? The stock market is already swinging wildly. What is the strike price of the Fed put?
